definition: palm of the hand/sole of the foot/paw/horseshoe/to slap/to hold in one's hand/to wield

sentences.english: And all that handle the oar, the mariners, and all the pilots of the sea, shall come down from their ships, they shall stand upon the land;
sentences.chinese: 凡荡桨的和水手，并一切泛海掌舵的，都必下船登岸。

sentences.english: The term tiller is also used for the steering arm of small outboard engines.
sentences.chinese: tiller这个术语也用来指舷外发动机的掌舵臂。

sentences.english: Then Wang Dan, a smart enterprise at the helm, he is not afraid?
sentences.chinese: 那么王石，一位精明的企业掌舵人，他不怕吗？

sentences.english: Life is like a boat, Eveybody must Learn to be skilled in boating.
sentences.chinese: 生命就像一只航船，每个人须学会如何掌舵。

sentences.english: The boat drifted along, with the child asleep inside it and no one guiding its direction.
sentences.chinese: 小船缓缓向前漂去，船上的孩子睡着了，无人掌舵。
他担任牛津大学赛船的掌舵人。

sentences.english: He held the wheel firmly to prevent the ship from broaching to.
sentences.chinese: 他牢牢掌舵，以防船侧面迎向风浪。

sentences.english: Ren is the man driving Huawei's growth.
sentences.chinese: 任正非是华为的掌舵人。

sentences.english: Organizationally, there will be a combination of some old and new faces at the race's helm.
sentences.chinese: 在组织上，将有一些新老组合在比赛中面临的掌舵人。

sentences.english: The boatman was just guiding it, there was no effort, for the wind was doing all the work.
sentences.chinese: 在风的吹送下，船夫没有努力，只是掌舵。

sentences.english: But the old man thought only of his steering and his great tiredness.
sentences.chinese: 老人此时想到的只是掌舵，和他自己极度的疲乏。

sentences.english: You are the guy who'll decide where to go.
sentences.chinese: 所以你是你人生的掌舵者。

sentences.english: He lay in the stern and steered and watched for the glow to come in the sky.
sentences.chinese: 他躺在船梢，一面掌舵，一面留意着天边红光的出现。

definition: to take over (as minister, manager etc)
to replace/to take over (a position or post)
to take up a post/to start in a new job
to go out to sea/to enter the sea (to swim etc)/(fig.) to take the plunge (e.g. leave a secure job, or enter prostitution etc)
to go out to sea/(neologism) to expand into overseas markets
to set sail on a voyage to a distant place/(fig.) to undertake a great mission
to take over (from those working the previous shift)/to take over (in a leadership role etc)/to succeed sb
